Sentence: At a hotel in the resort town of Vevey, Switzerland, a young American named Winterbourne meets a rich, pretty American girl named Daisy Miller, who is traveling around Europe with her (Daisy) mother and her (Daisy) younger brother, Randolph
Winterbourne, who has lived in Geneva most of his (Randolph) life, is both charmed and mystified by Daisy, who is less proper than the European girls he (Randolph) has encountered

Costello, his (Randolph) aunt, strongly disapproves of the Millers and flatly refuses to be introduced to Daisy, Winterbourne spends time with Daisy at Vevey and even accompanies her (Daisy), unchaperoned, to Chillon Castle, a famous local tourist attraction

The following winter, Winterbourne goes to Rome, knowing Daisy will be there, and is distressed to learn from his (tourist) aunt that she (Daisy) has taken up with a number of well-known fortune hunters and become the talk of the town
Giovanelli, of uncertain background, whose conduct with Daisy mystifies Winterbourne and scandalizes the American community in Rome
Walker and Winterbourne attempt to warn Daisy about the effect her (Daisy) behavior is having on her (Daisy) reputation, but she (Daisy) refuses to listen
Giovanelli, Winterbourne begins to have doubts about her (Daisy) character and how to interpret her (Daisy) behavior
Winterbourne is still concerned for Daisy's health, however, and he (Giovanelli) reproaches Giovanelli and urges him (Giovanelli) to get her (Daisy) safely home
Before dying, she (Daisy) gives her (Daisy) mother a message to pass on to Winterbourne that indicates that she (Daisy) cared what he (Giovanelli) thought about her (Daisy) after all
